segment.source: description: Retrieve or create the most current and popular Web content using syndicated feeds generated according to the RSS and Atom standards using features in the Windows.Web.Syndication namespace.
segment.target: description: Retrieve or create the most current and popular Web content using syndicated feeds generated according to the RSS and Atom standards using features in the Windows.Web.Syndication namespace.

segment.target: title: RSS/Atom feeds

segment.target: RSS/Atom feeds

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.Data.Xml.Dom
segment.target: Windows.Data.Xml.Dom

segment.source: Windows.Web.AtomPub
segment.target: Windows.Web.AtomPub

segment.source: Windows.Web.Syndication
segment.target: Windows.Web.Syndication

segment.source: Retrieve or create the most current and popular Web content using syndicated feeds generated according to the RSS and Atom standards using features in the Windows.Web.Syndication namespace.
segment.target: Retrieve or create the most current and popular Web content using syndicated feeds generated according to the RSS and Atom standards using features in the Windows.Web.Syndication namespace.

segment.source: What is a feed?
segment.target: What is a feed?

segment.source: A web feed is a document that contains any number of individual entries made up of text, links, and images.
segment.target: A web feed is a document that contains any number of individual entries made up of text, links, and images.

segment.source: Updates made to a feed are in the form of new entries used to promote the latest content across the Web.
segment.target: Updates made to a feed are in the form of new entries used to promote the latest content across the Web.

segment.source: Content consumers can use a feed reader app to aggregate and monitor feeds from any number of individual content authors, gaining access to the latest content quickly and conveniently.
segment.target: Content consumers can use a feed reader app to aggregate and monitor feeds from any number of individual content authors, gaining access to the latest content quickly and conveniently.

segment.source: Which feed format standards are supported?
segment.target: Which feed format standards are supported?

segment.source: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) supports feed retrieval for RSS format standards from 0.91 to RSS 2.0, and Atom standards from 0.3 to 1.0.
segment.target: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) supports feed retrieval for RSS format standards from 0.91 to RSS 2.0, and Atom standards from 0.3 to 1.0.

segment.source: Classes in the Windows.Web.Syndication namespace can define feeds and feed items capable of representing both RSS and Atom elements.
segment.target: Classes in the Windows.Web.Syndication namespace can define feeds and feed items capable of representing both RSS and Atom elements.

segment.source: Additionally, Atom 1.0 and RSS 2.0 formats both allow their feed documents to contain elements or attributes not defined in the official specifications.
segment.target: Additionally, Atom 1.0 and RSS 2.0 formats both allow their feed documents to contain elements or attributes not defined in the official specifications.

segment.source: Over time, these custom elements and attributes have become a way to define domain-specific information consumed by other web service data formats like GData and OData.
segment.target: Over time, these custom elements and attributes have become a way to define domain-specific information consumed by other web service data formats like GData and OData.

segment.source: To support this added feature, the SyndicationNode class represents generic XML elements.
segment.target: To support this added feature, the SyndicationNode class represents generic XML elements.

segment.source: Using SyndicationNode with classes in the Windows.Data.Xml.Dom namespace, allows apps to access attributes, extensions, and any content that they may contain.
segment.target: Using SyndicationNode with classes in the Windows.Data.Xml.Dom namespace, allows apps to access attributes, extensions, and any content that they may contain.

segment.source: Note that, for publication of syndicated content, the UWP implementation of the Atom Publication Protocol (Windows.Web.AtomPub) only supports feed content operations according to the Atom and Atom Publication standards.
segment.target: Note that, for publication of syndicated content, the UWP implementation of the Atom Publication Protocol (Windows.Web.AtomPub) only supports feed content operations according to the Atom and Atom Publication standards.

segment.source: Using syndicated content with network isolation
segment.target: Using syndicated content with network isolation

segment.source: The network isolation feature in the UWP enables a developer to control and limit network access by a UWP app.
segment.target: The network isolation feature in the UWP enables a developer to control and limit network access by a UWP app.

segment.source: Not all apps may require access to the network.
segment.target: Not all apps may require access to the network.

segment.source: However for those apps that do, UWP provides different levels of access to the network that can be enabled by selecting appropriate capabilities.
segment.target: However for those apps that do, UWP provides different levels of access to the network that can be enabled by selecting appropriate capabilities.

segment.source: Network isolation allows a developer to define for each app the scope of required network access.
segment.target: Network isolation allows a developer to define for each app the scope of required network access.

segment.source: An app without the appropriate scope defined is prevented from accessing the specified type of network, and specific type of network request (outbound client-initiated requests or both inbound unsolicited requests and outbound client-initiated requests).
segment.target: An app without the appropriate scope defined is prevented from accessing the specified type of network, and specific type of network request (outbound client-initiated requests or both inbound unsolicited requests and outbound client-initiated requests).

segment.source: The ability to set and enforce network isolation ensures that if an app does get compromised, it can only access networks where the app has explicitly been granted access.
segment.target: The ability to set and enforce network isolation ensures that if an app does get compromised, it can only access networks where the app has explicitly been granted access.

segment.source: This significantly reduces the scope of the impact on other applications and on Windows.
segment.target: This significantly reduces the scope of the impact on other applications and on Windows.

segment.source: Network isolation affects any class elements in the Windows.Web.Syndication and Windows.Web.AtomPub namespaces that try to access the network.
segment.target: Network isolation affects any class elements in the Windows.Web.Syndication and Windows.Web.AtomPub namespaces that try to access the network.

segment.source: Windows actively enforces network isolation.
segment.target: Windows actively enforces network isolation.

segment.source: A call to a class element in the Windows.Web.Syndication or Windows.Web.AtomPub namespace that results in network access may fail because of network isolation if the appropriate network capability has not been enabled.
segment.target: A call to a class element in the Windows.Web.Syndication or Windows.Web.AtomPub namespace that results in network access may fail because of network isolation if the appropriate network capability has not been enabled.

segment.source: The network capabilities for an app are configured in the app manifest when the app is built.
segment.target: The network capabilities for an app are configured in the app manifest when the app is built.

segment.source: Network capabilities are usually added using Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 when developing the app.
segment.target: Network capabilities are usually added using Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 when developing the app.

segment.source: Network capabilities may also be set manually in the app manifest file using a text editor.
segment.target: Network capabilities may also be set manually in the app manifest file using a text editor.

segment.source: For more detailed information on network isolation and networking capabilities, see the "Capabilities" section in the Networking basics topic.
segment.target: For more detailed information on network isolation and networking capabilities, see the "Capabilities" section in the Networking basics topic.

segment.source: How to access a web feed
segment.target: How to access a web feed

segment.source: This section shows how to retrieve and display a web feed using classes in the Windows.Web.Syndication namespace in your UWP app written in C# or Javascript.
segment.target: This section shows how to retrieve and display a web feed using classes in the Windows.Web.Syndication namespace in your UWP app written in C# or Javascript.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: To ensure your UWP app is network ready, you must set any network capabilities that are needed in the project Package.appxmanifest file.
segment.target: To ensure your UWP app is network ready, you must set any network capabilities that are needed in the project Package.appxmanifest file.

segment.source: If your app needs to connect as a client to remote services on the Internet, then the internetClient capability is needed.
segment.target: If your app needs to connect as a client to remote services on the Internet, then the internetClient capability is needed.

segment.source: For more information, see the "Capabilities" section in the Networking basics topic.
segment.target: For more information, see the "Capabilities" section in the Networking basics topic.

segment.source: Retrieving syndicated content from a web feed
segment.target: Retrieving syndicated content from a web feed

segment.source: Now we will review some code that demonstrates how to retrieve a feed, and then display each individual item that the feed contains.
segment.target: Now we will review some code that demonstrates how to retrieve a feed, and then display each individual item that the feed contains.

segment.source: Before we can configure and send the request, we'll define a few variables we'll be using during the operation, and initialize an instance of SyndicationClient, which defines the methods and properties we'll use to retrieve and display the feed.
segment.target: Before we can configure and send the request, we'll define a few variables we'll be using during the operation, and initialize an instance of SyndicationClient, which defines the methods and properties we'll use to retrieve and display the feed.

segment.source: The Uri constructor throws an exception if the uriString passed to the constructor is not a valid URI.
segment.target: The Uri constructor throws an exception if the uriString passed to the constructor is not a valid URI.

segment.source: So we validate the uriString using a try/catch block.
segment.target: So we validate the uriString using a try/catch block.

segment.source: [!div class="tabbedCodeSnippets"]
segment.target: [!div class="tabbedCodeSnippets"]

segment.source: Next we configure the request by setting any Server credentials (the ServerCredential property), proxy credentials (the ProxyCredential property), and HTTP headers (the SetRequestHeader method) needed.
segment.target: Next we configure the request by setting any Server credentials (the ServerCredential property), proxy credentials (the ProxyCredential property), and HTTP headers (the SetRequestHeader method) needed.

segment.source: With the basic request parameters configured, a valid Uri object, created using a feed URI string provided by the app.
segment.target: With the basic request parameters configured, a valid Uri object, created using a feed URI string provided by the app.

segment.source: The Uri object is then passed to the RetrieveFeedAsync function to request the feed.
segment.target: The Uri object is then passed to the RetrieveFeedAsync function to request the feed.

segment.source: Assuming the desired feed content was returned, the example code iterates through each feed item, calling displayCurrentItem (which we define next), to display items and their contents as a list through the UI.
segment.target: Assuming the desired feed content was returned, the example code iterates through each feed item, calling displayCurrentItem (which we define next), to display items and their contents as a list through the UI.

segment.source: You must write code to handle exceptions when you call most asynchronous network methods.
segment.target: You must write code to handle exceptions when you call most asynchronous network methods.

segment.source: Your exception handler can retrieve more detailed information on the cause of the exception to better understand the failure and make appropriate decisions.
segment.target: Your exception handler can retrieve more detailed information on the cause of the exception to better understand the failure and make appropriate decisions.

segment.source: The RetrieveFeedAsync method throws an exception if a connection could not be established with the HTTP server or the Uri object does not point to a valid AtomPub or RSS feed.
segment.target: The RetrieveFeedAsync method throws an exception if a connection could not be established with the HTTP server or the Uri object does not point to a valid AtomPub or RSS feed.

segment.source: The Javascript sample code uses an onError function to catch any exceptions and print out more detailed information on the exception if an error occurs.
segment.target: The Javascript sample code uses an onError function to catch any exceptions and print out more detailed information on the exception if an error occurs.

segment.source: [!div class="tabbedCodeSnippets"]
segment.target: [!div class="tabbedCodeSnippets"]

segment.source: In the previous step, RetrieveFeedAsync returned the requested feed content and the example code got to work iterating through available feed items.
segment.target: In the previous step, RetrieveFeedAsync returned the requested feed content and the example code got to work iterating through available feed items.

segment.source: Each of these items is represented using a SyndicationItem object that contains all of the item properties and content afforded by the relevant syndication standard (RSS or Atom).
segment.target: Each of these items is represented using a SyndicationItem object that contains all of the item properties and content afforded by the relevant syndication standard (RSS or Atom).

segment.source: In the following example we observe the displayCurrentItem function working through each item and displaying its content through various named UI elements.
segment.target: In the following example we observe the displayCurrentItem function working through each item and displaying its content through various named UI elements.

segment.source: [!div class="tabbedCodeSnippets"]
segment.target: [!div class="tabbedCodeSnippets"]

segment.source: As suggested earlier, the type of content represented by a SyndicationItem object will differ depending on the feed standard (RSS or Atom) employed to publish the feed.
segment.target: As suggested earlier, the type of content represented by a SyndicationItem object will differ depending on the feed standard (RSS or Atom) employed to publish the feed.

segment.source: For example, an Atom feed is capable of providing a list of Contributors, but an RSS feed is not.
segment.target: For example, an Atom feed is capable of providing a list of Contributors, but an RSS feed is not.

segment.source: However, extension elements included in a feed item that are not supported by either standard (e.g., Dublin Core extension elements) can be accessed using the SyndicationItem.ElementExtensions property and then displayed as demonstrated in the following example code.
segment.target: However, extension elements included in a feed item that are not supported by either standard (e.g., Dublin Core extension elements) can be accessed using the SyndicationItem.ElementExtensions property and then displayed as demonstrated in the following example code.
